You are correct that the Crusades did contribute to the spread of diseases like the bubonic plague due to the large numbers of people traveling to and from the Holy Land. However, it is important to remember that people during the medieval period did not have the same understanding of medicine and disease that we do today.

Moreover, the potential benefits of participating in the Crusades were significant enough that many people were willing to take the risk. For example, the merchants saw the Crusades as an opportunity to gain access to new markets and customers for their goods. Similarly, the nobility saw the Crusades as a way to expand their wealth and power.

Additionally, the religious motivations behind the Crusades cannot be overlooked. For many Europeans, the Crusades were seen as a holy mission to reclaim the Holy Land from the infidels. The idea of earning salvation or atoning for sins was a powerful motivator for many people.

Overall, while the risks associated with the Crusades were significant, the potential benefits, both economic and religious, were powerful motivators for many people to take the risk and participate in the Crusades.
